<A NAME="eolPage70"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Our Charters
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We generate revenues by charging our customers for the use of our vessels to transport their dry cargos. In general, the vessels in our fleet are chartered-out
	under time charters, which range in length from one to eleven years at inception. From time to time, we operate vessels in the spot market until the vessels have been chartered under long-term charters.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, Navios Partners&#146; customers representing 10% or more of total revenues were Hyundai Merchant Marine Co., Ltd.,
	Navios Corporation and Yang Ming Marine Transport Corporation, which accounted for approximately 24.0%, 17.4% and 11.4%, respectively, of total revenues. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, Navios Partners&#146; customers representing 10% or
	more of total revenues were Hyundai Merchant Marine Co., Ltd and Navios Corporation, which accounted for 24.4% and 11.0%, respectively, of total revenues. We believe that the combination of the long-term nature of our charters (which provide for the
	receipt of a fixed fee for the life of the charter) and our management agreement with the Manager, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Navios Holdings (which provides for a fixed management fee until December&nbsp;31, 2017), provides us with a strong base
	of stable cash flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our revenues are driven by the number of vessels in the fleet, the number of days during which the vessels operate and our charter
	hire rates, which, in turn, are affected by a number of factors, including:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the duration of the charters;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the level of spot and long-term market rates at the time of charter;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	decisions relating to vessel acquisitions and disposals;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the amount of time spent positioning vessels;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the amount of time that vessels spend undergoing repairs and upgrades in drydock;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the age, condition and specifications of the vessels; and
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the aggregate level of supply and demand in the dry cargo shipping industry.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Time charters are available for
	varying periods, ranging from a single trip (spot charter) to long-term which may be many years. In general, a long-term time charter assures the vessel owner of a consistent stream of revenue. Operating the vessel in the spot market affords the
	owner greater spot market opportunity, which may result in high rates when vessels are in high demand or low rates when vessel availability exceeds demand. We intend to operate our vessels in the long-term charter market. Vessel charter rates are
	affected by world economics, international events, weather conditions, strikes, governmental policies, supply and demand and many other factors that might be beyond our control.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We could lose a customer or the benefits of a charter if:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the customer fails to make charter payments because of its financial inability, disagreements with us or otherwise;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the customer exercises certain rights to terminate the charter of the vessel;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the customer terminates the charter because we fail to deliver the vessel within a fixed period of time, the vessel is lost or damaged beyond repair, there are serious deficiencies in the vessel or prolonged periods of
	off-hire, or we default under the charter;&nbsp;or
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	a prolonged force majeure event affecting the customer, including damage to or destruction of relevant production facilities, war or political unrest prevents us from performing services for that customer.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under some of our time charters, either party may terminate the charter contract in the event of war in specified countries or in locations
	that would significantly disrupt the free trade of the vessel. Some of the time charters
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	68
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage71"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	covering our vessels require us to return to the charterer, upon the loss of the vessel, all advances paid by the charterer but not earned by us.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Vessel Operations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under our charters, our vessel manager
	is generally responsible for commercial, technical, health and safety and other management services related to the vessels&#146; operation, and the charterer is responsible for bunkering and substantially all of the vessel voyage costs, including
	canal tolls and port charges.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under the management agreement we entered into with the Manager, the Manager bears all of our vessel operating expenses in
	exchange for the payment of fees as described below. Under this agreement, the Manager is responsible for commercial, technical, health and safety and other management services related to the vessels&#146; operation, including chartering, technical
	support and maintenance, insurance but costs associated with special surveys and related drydockings will be reimbursed by Navios Partners at cost at occurrence. In October&nbsp;2011, Navios Partners extended the duration of its existing Management
	Agreement with the Manager until December&nbsp;31, 2017 and the fixed rate for ship management services of its owned fleet through December&nbsp;31, 2013. The management fees, including drydocking expenses were: (a)&nbsp;$4,650 daily rate per
	Ultra-Handymax vessel; (b)&nbsp;$4,550 daily rate per Panamax vessel; and (c)&nbsp;$5,650 daily rate per Capesize vessel. In each of October 2013,&nbsp;August 2014,&nbsp;February 2015 and February 2016, Navios&nbsp;Partners amended its existing
	management agreement with the Manager to fix the fees for ship management services of its owned fleet excluding drydocking expenses which are reimbursed at cost by Navios Partners at: (a)&nbsp;$4,100 daily rate per Ultra-Handymax vessel;
	(b)&nbsp;$4,200 daily rate per Panamax vessel; (c)&nbsp;$5,250 daily rate per Capesize vessel; (d)&nbsp;$6,700 daily rate per Container vessel of TEU 6,800; (e)&nbsp;$7,400 daily rate per Container vessel of more than TEU 8,000; and (f)&nbsp;$8,750
	daily rate per very large Container vessel of more than TEU 13,000 through December&nbsp;31, 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Extraordinary costs and expenses include fees and
	costs resulting from:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	time spent on insurance and salvage claims;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	time spent vetting and pre-vetting the vessels by any charterers in excess of 10&nbsp;days&nbsp;per vessel per year;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	the deductible of any insurance claims relating to the vessels or for any claims that are within such deductible range;
</TD>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	repairs, refurbishment or modifications, including those not covered by the guarantee of the shipbuilder or by the insurance covering the vessels, resulting from maritime accidents, collisions, other accidental damage
	or unforeseen events (except to the extent that such accidents, collisions, damage or events are due to the fraud, gross negligence or willful misconduct of the Manager, its employees or its agents, unless and to the extent otherwise covered by
	insurance);
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	change in the interpretation of, applicable laws, at the recommendation of the classification society for that vessel or otherwise;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	any similar costs, liabilities and expenses that were not reasonably contemplated by us and the Manager as being encompassed by or a component of the fixed daily fees at the time the fixed daily fees were determined.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Payment of any extraordinary fees or expenses to the Manager could significantly increase our vessel operating expenses and impact our
	results of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the remaining term of the management agreement, we expect that we will reimburse the Manager for all of the actual
	operating costs and expenses it incurs in connection with the management of our fleet.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Administrative Services
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under the Administrative Services Agreement we entered into with the Manager, we reimburse the Manager for reasonable costs and expenses incurred in connection
	with the provision of the services under this agreement within 15&nbsp;days after the Manager submits to us an invoice for such costs and expenses, together with any supporting detail that may be reasonably required. Under this agreement which
	expires in December 2017, the Manager provides significant administrative, financial and other support services to us.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Trends and Factors Affecting
	Our Future Results of Operations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We believe the principal factors that will affect our future results of operations are the economic, regulatory,
	political and governmental conditions that affect the shipping industry generally and that affect conditions in countries and markets in which our vessels engage in business. Other key factors that will be fundamental to our business, future
	financial condition and results of operations include:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Time charter and voyage revenues:
</B>
	Time charter and voyage revenues for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 decreased
	by $3.7&nbsp;million or 1.6% to $223.7&nbsp;million, as compared to $227.4&nbsp;million for the same period in 2014. The decrease was mainly attributable to the decrease in TCE to $19,739 per day for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, from
	$20,306 per day for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The above decrease in time charter and voyage revenues was partially mitigated by an increase in revenue due to the delivery of the Navios La Paix and the Navios Sun in January 2014, the YM
	Utmost and the YM Unity in the second half of 2014 and the delivery of the MSC Cristina in April 2015. As a result of the vessel acquisitions, available days of the fleet increased to 11,051&nbsp;days for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, as
	compared to 10,927&nbsp;days for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Time charter and voyage expenses:
</B>
	Time charter and voyage expenses for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 decreased by $8.2&nbsp;million or 53.2% to $7.2&nbsp;million, as compared to $15.4 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease was mainly attributable to the termination of the charter-in
	contracts of the Navios Prosperity and the Navios Aldebaran in the first quarter of 2015. On February&nbsp;11, 2015, Navios Partners and Navios Holdings entered into a novation agreement whereby the rights to the time charter contracts of the Navios
	Aldebaran and the Navios Prosperity were transferred to Navios Holdings as of February&nbsp;28, 2015 and March&nbsp;5, 2015, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Direct
	vessel expenses:
</B>
	Direct vessel expenses, comprising of the amortization of dry dock and special survey costs, of certain vessels in our fleet amounted to $4.0 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, as compared to $0.8 million for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The increase of $3.3 million was due to drydocks performed in advance during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Management fees:
</B>
	&nbsp;Management fees for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, increased by $6.2&nbsp;million or 12.2% to $56.5&nbsp;million, as
	compared to $50.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The increase was mainly attributable to the increased number of owned vessels in Navios Partners&#146; fleet.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	71
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage74"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Pursuant to the Management Agreement, the Manager, a wholly owned subsidiary of Navios Holdings, provides
	commercial and technical management services to Navios Partners&#146; vessels for a daily fee of: (a)&nbsp;$4,000 daily rate per Ultra-Handymax vessel; (b)&nbsp;$4,100 daily rate per Panamax vessel; (c)&nbsp;$5,100 daily rate per Capesize vessel;
	(d)&nbsp;$6,500 daily rate per Container vessel of TEU 6,800; (e)&nbsp;$7,200 daily rate per Container vessel of more than TEU 8,000; and (f)&nbsp;$8,500 daily rate per very large Container vessel of more than TEU 13,000 through December&nbsp;31,
	2015. In January 2016, Navios&nbsp;Partners amended its existing management agreement with the Manager to fix the fees for ship management services of its owned fleet excluding drydocking expenses which will be reimbursed at cost by Navios Partners
	at: (a)&nbsp;$4,100 daily rate per Ultra-Handymax vessel; (b)&nbsp;$4,200 daily rate per Panamax vessel; (c)&nbsp;$5,250 daily rate per Capesize vessel; (d)&nbsp;$6,700 daily rate per Container vessel of TEU 6,800; (e)&nbsp;$7,400 daily rate per
	Container vessel of more than TEU 8,000; and (f)&nbsp;$8,750 daily rate per very large Container vessel of more than TEU 13,000 through December&nbsp;31, 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	General and administrative expenses:
</B>
	&nbsp;General and administrative expenses increased by $0.1 million or 1.2% to $7.9&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, as compared to $7.8 million&nbsp;for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The increase was mainly attributable to the increase in administrative fees paid to the Manager due to the increased number of vessels in Navios
	Partners&#146; fleet.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Pursuant to the Administrative Services Agreement, the Manager also provides administrative services to Navios Partners, which
	include bookkeeping, audit and accounting services, legal and insurance services, administrative and clerical services, banking and financial services, advisory services, client and investor relations and other. The Manager is reimbursed for
	reasonable costs and expenses incurred in connection with the provision of these services. Navios Partners extended the duration of its existing Administrative Services Agreement with the Manager pursuant to the same terms, until December&nbsp;31,
	2017. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, the expenses charged by the Manager for administrative fees were $6.2&nbsp;million and $6.1&nbsp;million, respectively. The balance of $1.7&nbsp;million and $1.8&nbsp;million of general and
	administrative expenses, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively, related to legal and professional fees, as well as audit fees and directors&#146; fees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Depreciation and amortization:
</B>
	&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization amounted to $75.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to
	$95.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease of $19.9&nbsp;million was attributable to: (a)&nbsp;a&nbsp;$22.0 million accelerated amortization of the Navios Pollux favorable lease intangible due to change in its useful
	life in 2014 (Refer to Note 7 &#151; Intangible Assets for further details); and (b)&nbsp;a $6.3 million decrease of amortization of the intangibles which were written off in the first quarter of 2014 for the Navios Orbiter, the Navios Hyperion and
	the Navios Pollux and the intangible for the Navios Fulvia which was written off in third quarter of 2015. The above decrease was primarily mitigated by&nbsp;an increase in depreciation expense of $6.7&nbsp;million due to the increased number of
	vessels that were delivered into our owned fleet. Depreciation of vessels is calculated using an estimated useful life of 25 and 30&nbsp;years for drybulk and container vessels, respectively, from the date the vessel was originally delivered from
	the shipyard. Intangible assets are amortized over the contract periods, which range from one to ten years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Interest expense and finance cost,
	net:
</B>
	Interest expense and finance cost, net for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 increased by $3.0&nbsp;million or 10.3% to $31.7&nbsp;million, as compared to $28.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The increase was
	due to&nbsp;the increase in the average outstanding loan balance to $605.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 from $547.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 mitigated by&nbsp;the lower weighted average
	interest rate of 4.44% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to 4.69% for the same period in 2014. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, the outstanding loan balance under Navios Partners&#146; credit facilities was
	$603.4&nbsp;million and $583.3 million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Interest income:
</B>
	Interest income decreased by $0.02&nbsp;million to $0.22&nbsp;million for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, as compared to $0.25&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Other income:
</B>
	Other income for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 amounted to $5.2&nbsp;million compared to $47.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease was mainly attributable to the compensation
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	72
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage75"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	received of $47.6 million from our third-party insurer for the termination of the credit default insurance in the first quarter of 2014, which resulted in a gain of $47.6 million. Other income
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, mainly is attributable to the $3.6 million relating to claims submitted under Navios Holdings Guarantee agreement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Other expense:
</B>
	Other expense increased by $2.3&nbsp;million to $4.0 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, as compared to $1.7 million for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Net income:
</B>
	Net income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 amounted to $41.8&nbsp;million compared to
	$74.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease in net income of $33.0&nbsp;million was due to the factors discussed above.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Operating surplus:
</B>
	Navios Partners generated an Operating Surplus for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 of $112.7 million, as compared to $150.2
	million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. Operating Surplus is a non-GAAP financial measure used by certain investors to assist in evaluating a partnership&#146;s ability to make quarterly cash distributions (See &#147;Reconciliation of
	EBITDA to Net Cash from Operating Activities&#148; and &#147;Suspension of Distributions&#148; contained herein).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Seasonality:
</B>
	&nbsp;Since Navios
	Partners&#146; vessels generally operate under long-term charters, the results of operations are not generally subject to the effect of seasonable variations in demand.
</P>

</B>
</P>

	from the audited consolidated revenue and expense accounts of Navios Partners for the respective periods.

<B>
	Year Ended

	December&nbsp;31,

	(In&nbsp;thousands&nbsp;of

	U.S dollars)

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Time charter and voyage revenues:
</B>
	Time charter and voyage revenues for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 increased
	by $29.2&nbsp;million or 14.7% to $227.4&nbsp;million, as compared to $198.2 million for the same period in 2013. The increase was mainly attributable to the delivery of: (i)&nbsp;the Navios Joy, the Navios Harmony and the five container vessels in
	the second half of 2013; and (ii)&nbsp;the Navios La Paix, the Navios Sun, the YM Utmost
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	73
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage76"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	and the YM Unity in 2014. As a result of the vessel acquisitions, available days of the fleet increased to 10,927&nbsp;days for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, as compared to
	7,952&nbsp;days for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The above increase in time charter and voyage revenues was partially mitigated by the decrease in TCE to $20,306 per day for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, from $24,284 per day for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, which was primarily due to the decline in the freight market during 2014 as compared to the same period in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Time charter and voyage expenses:
</B>
	Time charter and voyage expenses for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 increased by $0.5&nbsp;million or 3.0% to
	$15.4&nbsp;million, as compared to $14.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase was mainly attributable to an increase in bunkers expenses incurred during the year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Management fees:
</B>
	&nbsp;Management fees for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, increased by $14.2&nbsp;million or 39.2% to $50.4&nbsp;million, as
	compared to $36.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase was mainly attributable to the increased number of owned vessels in Navios Partners&#146; fleet.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Pursuant to the Management Agreement, the Manager, a wholly owned subsidiary of Navios Holdings, provides commercial and technical management services to
	Navios Partners&#146; vessels for a daily fee of: (a)&nbsp;$4,000 daily rate per Ultra-Handymax vessel; (b)&nbsp;$4,100 daily rate per Panamax vessel; (c)&nbsp;$5,100 daily rate per Capesize vessel; (d)&nbsp;$6,500 daily rate per Container vessel of
	TEU 6,800; (e)&nbsp;$7,200 daily rate per Container vessel of more than TEU 8,000; and (f)&nbsp;$8,500 daily rate per very large Container vessel of more than TEU 13,000 through December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	General and administrative expenses:
</B>
	&nbsp;General and administrative expenses increased by $1.5 million or 24.3% to $7.8&nbsp;million for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, as compared to $6.3 million&nbsp;for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase was mainly attributable to the increase in administrative fees paid to the Manager due to the increased number of vessels in
	Navios Partners&#146; fleet.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Pursuant to the Administrative Services Agreement, the Manager also provides administrative services to Navios Partners,
	which include bookkeeping, audit and accounting services, legal and insurance services, administrative and clerical services, banking and financial services, advisory services, client and investor relations and other. The Manager is reimbursed for
	reasonable costs and expenses incurred in connection with the provision of these services. Navios Partners extended the duration of its existing Administrative Services Agreement with the Manager pursuant to the same terms, until December&nbsp;31,
	2017. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013, the expenses charged by the Manager for administrative fees were $6.1&nbsp;million and $4.4&nbsp;million, respectively. The balance of $1.8&nbsp;million and $1.9&nbsp;million of general and
	administrative expenses, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013, respectively, related to legal and professional fees, as well as audit fees and directors&#146; fees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Depreciation and amortization:
</B>
	&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization amounted to $95.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to
	$77.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase of $18.3&nbsp;million was attributable to: (a)&nbsp;an increase in depreciation expense of $14.0&nbsp;million due to the increased number of vessels that were delivered into
	our owned fleet; and (b)&nbsp;a&nbsp;$22.0 million accelerated amortization of the Navios Pollux favorable lease intangible due to a change in its useful life (Refer to Note 7 &#151; Intangible Assets of our notes to the consolidated financial
	statements for further details). The above increase was partially mitigated by a $14.6 million decrease of amortization due to write-offs of favorable lease of the Navios Orbiter, the Navios Hyperion and the Navios Pollux in the first quarter of
	2014 and the write-off of the Navios Melodia favorable lease in the second quarter of 2013 of $3.2 million. Depreciation of vessels is calculated using an estimated useful life of 25 and 30&nbsp;years for drybulk and container vessels, respectively,
	from the date the vessel was originally delivered from the shipyard. Intangible assets are amortized over the contract periods, which range from one to eight years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	74
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage77"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Interest expense and finance cost, net:
</B>
	Interest expense and finance cost, net for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 increased by $11.9&nbsp;million or 70.1% to $28.8&nbsp;million, as compared to $16.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase was due to: (a)&nbsp;the higher weighted average interest rate of 4.69%
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, compared to 3.67% for the same period in 2013; and (b)&nbsp;the increase in the average outstanding loan balance to $547.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 from $353.1&nbsp;million for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. As of December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013, the outstanding loan balance under Navios Partners&#146; credit facilities was $583.3&nbsp;million and $533.3&nbsp;million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Interest income:
</B>
	Interest income increased by $0.2&nbsp;million to $0.25&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, as compared to
	$0.05&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Other income:
</B>
	Other income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 amounted to
	$47.9&nbsp;million compared to $13.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase in other income by $34.2 million was mainly due to: (i)&nbsp;a $17.8 million cash compensation received during 2014 from the sale of a
	defaulted counterparty claim to an unrelated third party; and (ii)&nbsp;$29.8 million compensation received during 2014 following the termination of the amended credit default insurance policy. During 2013, other income was $13.7 million mainly
	related to $10.0 million compensation recognized covering hire revenues for the suspension period in a drybulk charter contract until April 2016. (See also Note 20&#151;Other Income of our notes to the consolidated financial statements).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Other expense:
</B>
	Other expense increased by $0.7&nbsp;million to $1.7 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, as compared to $1.1 million for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Net income:
</B>
	Net income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 amounted to $74.9&nbsp;million compared to
	$59.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase in net income of $15.8&nbsp;million was due to the factors discussed above.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Operating surplus:
</B>
	Navios Partners generated an Operating Surplus for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 of $150.2 million, as compared to $125.5
	million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. Operating Surplus is a non-GAAP financial measure used by certain investors to assist in evaluating a partnership&#146;s ability to make quarterly cash distributions (See &#147;Reconciliation of
	EBITDA to Net Cash from Operating Activities&#148; and &#147;Suspension of Distributions&#148; contained herein).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Seasonality:
</B>
	&nbsp;Since Navios
	Partners&#146; vessels generally operate under long-term charters, the results of operations are not generally subject to the effect of seasonable variations in demand.
</P>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	B. Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Credit facilities
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In June 2013, Navios Partners completed the issuance of the $250.0 million Term Loan B facility. The Term Loan B facility bears an interest rate of
	LIBOR plus 425 basis points (&#147;bps&#148;) and has a five-year term with 1.0% amortization profile and was issued at 98.0% (at a discount of $5.0 million). Navios Partners used the net proceeds of the Term Loan B facility to: (i)&nbsp;prepay
	$101.6 million of the July 2012 Credit Facility; (ii)&nbsp;fully repay the outstanding balance of $41.2 million of the credit facility entered with DVB Bank AG on August&nbsp;8, 2012 (the &#147;August 2012 Credit Facility&#148;); (iii)&nbsp;deposit
	$98.2 million to be held in escrow, to partially finance part of the acquisition of four new vessels, of which $47.0 million was released in September 2013 for the acquisition of the Navios Joy, $17.8 million was released in October 2013 for the
	acquisition of the Navios Harmony and $33.4 million was released in January 2014 to finance a portion of the purchase prices of the Navios Sun and the Navios La Paix, which were delivered in January 2014; and (iv)&nbsp;cover fees and expenses. The
	refinancing of the August 2012 Credit Facility was accounted for as a debt extinguishment in accordance with ASC470 Debt and the remaining unamortized balance of $0.7 million was written-off from the deferred financing fees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	75
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage78"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;1, 2013, Navios Partners completed the issuance of a $189.5 million add-on to its existing Term
	Loan B facility. The add-on to the Term Loan B facility bears the same terms as Term Loan B facility and was issued at 100%. Navios Partners used the net proceeds to partially finance the acquisition of five Container vessels.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On March&nbsp;30, 2015 and on March&nbsp;23, 2016, Navios Partners prepaid $21.0 million and $3.0 million, respectively, of the Term Loan B facility. These
	prepayments were fully applied to the balloon payment. Following the prepayment of March 2015, an amount of $0.3 million was written-off from the deferred financing fees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Term Loan B facility is secured by first priority mortgages covering certain vessels owned by subsidiaries of Navios Partners, in addition to other
	collateral and is guaranteed by each subsidiary of Navios Partners. The Term Loan B Agreement requires maintenance of a loan to value ratio of 0.8 to 1.0, and other restrictive covenants customary for facilities of this type (subject to negotiated
	exceptions and baskets), including restrictions on indebtedness, liens, acquisitions and investments, restricted payments and dispositions. The Term Loan B Agreement also provides for customary events of default, prepayment and cure provisions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the outstanding balance of the Term Loan B facility including the add-on was $408.8 million, net of discount of $2.5 million,
	and it is repayable with a final payment of $411.3 million, in June 2018.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On September&nbsp;22, 2014, Navios Partners entered into the September 2014
	Credit Facility (divided into two tranches) in order to finance a portion of the purchase price payable in connection with the acquisition of the YM Utmost and the YM Unity. Each tranche of the September 2014 Credit Facility was repayable in 20
	equal quarterly installments of approximately $0.7 million, with a final balloon payment of $14.3 million on the last repayment date. The maturity date of each tranche was five years after the drawdown date of such tranche. The tranches of the
	September 2014 Credit Facility bear interest at LIBOR plus 300&nbsp;bps&nbsp;per annum. On March&nbsp;30, 2015, Navios Partners prepaid $21.3 million out of $53.9 million outstanding on that date. Following this prepayment, an amount of $0.3 million
	was written-off from the deferred financing fees. On April&nbsp;8, 2015, Navios Partners entered into a supplemental agreement (the &#147;First Supplemental Agreement&#148;) to its September 2014 Credit Facility following the release and discharge
	of Fairy Shipping Corporation and the YM Utmost from its obligations and liabilities under the September 2014 Credit Facility pursuant to a deed of release dated March&nbsp;30, 2015. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the outstanding balance of the loan
	was $29.4 million, and is repayable in 16 consecutive quarterly installments, the first 11 of which are $1.1 million and the next five are $0.7 million, with a final balloon payment of $14.3 million on the last repayment date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On March&nbsp;27, 2015, Navios Partners prepaid $2.3 million of the July 2012 Credit facility and the prepayment was applied to 2015 installments. As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, the outstanding balance of the July 2012 Credit facility was $88.3 million, and it was repayable in seven installments of $3.5 million and one installment of $5.9&nbsp;million, with a final balloon payment of $58.2 million.
	On January&nbsp;8, 2016, Navios Partners prepaid the 2016 installments of the July 2012 Credit facility in the amount of $16.2 million. This payment of this facility was accounted for as debt modification in accordance with ASC470 Debt.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On April&nbsp;16, 2015, Navios Partners, through certain of its wholly-owned subsidiaries, entered into the April 2015 Credit Facility (divided into two
	tranches), in order to finance a portion of the purchase price payable in connection with the acquisition of the MSC Cristina and one more super-post-panamax 13,100 TEU container vessel. In September&nbsp;30, 2015, the second tranche of April 2015
	Credit Facility of $83.0 million was cancelled. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the outstanding balance of the April 2015 Credit Facility of $76.9 million was drawn on April&nbsp;20, 2015, is repayable in 26 equal consecutive quarterly installments of
	$1.5 million, with a final balloon payment of $38.4 million on the last repayment date. The final maturity date is April&nbsp;20, 2022. The April 2015 Credit Facility bears interest at LIBOR plus 275 bps per annum. The April 2015 Credit Facility
	also requires compliance with certain financial covenants. Among other events, it will be an event of default under this credit facility if the financial covenants are not complied with.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	76
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage79"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In May 2015, Navios Partners entered into a term loan facility with Navios Holdings of up to $60.0 million (the
	&#147;Navios Holdings Credit Facility&#148;). The Navios Holdings Credit Facility has a margin of LIBOR plus 300 bps. The final maturity date is January&nbsp;2, 2017. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, there was no outstanding amount under this facility
	and all $60.0 million remained to be drawn.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the total amount available to be drawn from all Navios Partners&#146; credit
	facilities was $60.0 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the total borrowings, net under the Navios Partners&#146; credit facilities were
	$598.1&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Amounts drawn under the July 2012 Credit Facility are secured by first preferred mortgages on certain Navios Partners&#146; vessels
	and other collateral and are guaranteed by the respective vessel-owning subsidiary. Amounts drawn under the September 2014 Credit Facility and the April 2015 Credit Facility are secured by first preferred mortgages on certain Navios Partners&#146;
	vessels and other collateral and are guaranteed by Navios Partners. The July 2012 Credit Facility, the September 2014 Credit Facility and April 2015 Credit Facility contain a number of restrictive covenants that prohibit or limit Navios Partners
	from, among other things: incurring or guaranteeing indebtedness; entering into affiliate transactions; charging, pledging or encumbering the vessels; changing the flag, class, management or ownership of Navios Partners&#146; vessels; changing the
	commercial and technical management of Navios Partners&#146; vessels; selling or changing the beneficial ownership or control of Navios Partners&#146; vessels; not maintaining Navios Holdings&#146; (or its affiliates) ownership in Navios Partners of
	at least 15.0%; and subordinating the obligations under the credit facilities to any general and administrative costs relating to the vessels, including the fixed daily fee payable under the management agreement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The July 2012 Credit Facility, the September 2014 Credit Facility and April 2015 Credit Facility also require compliance with a number of financial covenants,
	including: (i)&nbsp;maintain a required security amount ranging over 117% to 140%; (ii)&nbsp;minimum free consolidated liquidity of at least the higher of $25.0 million and the aggregate of interest and principal falling due during the previous six
	months; (iii)&nbsp;maintain a ratio of EBITDA to interest expense of at least 2.00 : 1.00; (iv)&nbsp;maintain a ratio of total liabilities to total assets (as defined in our credit facilities) of less than&nbsp;0.75&nbsp;:&nbsp;1.00; and
	(v)&nbsp;maintain a minimum net worth to $135.0 million for the periods prior to any distributions by the Company, whilst during the last quarter prior to any distribution declaration should maintain: (a)&nbsp;a ratio of EBITDA to interest expense
	of at least 5.00 : 1.00; (b)&nbsp;a ratio of total liabilities to total assets (as defined in our credit facilities) of less than&nbsp;0.65&nbsp;:&nbsp;1.00; and (c)&nbsp;a minimum net worth of $250.0 million. It is an event of default under the
	credit facilities if such covenants are not complied with in accordance with the terms and subject to the prepayment or cure provision of each facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, Navios Partners was in compliance with the financial covenants and/or the prepayment and/or the cure provisions as applicable in
	each of its credit facilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The credit facilities prohibit us from paying distributions to our unitholders or making new investments if, before and
	after giving effect to such distribution or investment we are not in compliance with the financial covenants described above or upon the occurrence of an event of default. Events of default under our credit facilities include:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	vessel-owning subsidiaries or any of the assets of the vessel-owning subsidiaries and failure to maintain proper insurance and in some cases subject to certain grace and due periods;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Liquidity and Cash Sources and Uses
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition to
	distributions on our units, our primary short-term liquidity needs are to fund general working capital requirements, cash reserve requirements including those under our credit facilities and debt service, while our long-term liquidity needs
	primarily relate to expansion and investment capital expenditures and other maintenance capital expenditures and debt repayment. Expansion capital expenditures are primarily for the purchase or construction of vessels to the extent the expenditures
	increase the operating capacity of or revenue generated by our fleet, while maintenance capital expenditures primarily consist of drydocking expenditures and expenditures to replace vessels in order to maintain the operating capacity of or revenue
	generated by our fleet. Investment capital expenditures are those capital expenditures that are neither maintenance capital expenditures nor expansion capital expenditures.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We anticipate that our primary sources of funds for our short-term liquidity needs will be cash flows from operations proceeds from asset sales and bank
	borrowings. As of December 31, 2015, Navios Partners&#146; current assets totaled $39.8 million, while current liabilities totaled $41.5 million, resulting in a negative working capital position of $1.7 million. Generally, our long-term sources of
	funds derive from cash from operations, long-term bank borrowings and other debt or equity financings to fund acquisitions and expansion and investment capital expenditures, including opportunities we may pursue under the Omnibus Agreement. We
	cannot assure you that we will be able to raise the size of our credit facilities or obtaining additional funds on favorable terms.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash deposits and
	cash equivalents in excess of amounts covered by government provided insurance are exposed to loss in the event of non-performance by financial institutions. Navios Partners does maintain cash deposits and equivalents in excess of government
	provided insurance limits. Navios Partners also minimizes exposure to credit risk by dealing with a diversified group of major financial institutions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As
	of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the total amount available to be drawn from all Navios Partners&#146; credit facilities was $60.0 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, the total borrowings, net under the Navios Partners&#146; credit facilities were $598.1&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;6, 2013,
	Navios Partners completed its public offering of 4,500,000 common units at $14.15 per unit and raised gross proceeds of approximately $63.7&nbsp;million to fund its fleet expansion. The net proceeds of this offering, including the underwriting
	discount and excluding offering costs at $0.2&nbsp;million were approximately $60.8&nbsp;million. Pursuant to this offering, Navios Partners issued 91,837 general partnership units to its general partner. The net proceeds from the issuance of the
	general partnership units were $1.3&nbsp;million. On the same date, Navios Partners completed the exercise of the option previously granted to the underwriters in connection with the offering and issued 675,000 additional common units at the public
	offering price less the
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	78
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage81"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	underwriting discount. As a result of the exercise of the option, Navios Partners raised additional gross proceeds of $9.6&nbsp;million and net proceeds, including the underwriting discount, of
	approximately $9.1&nbsp;million and issued 13,776 additional general partnership units to its general partner. The net proceeds from the issuance of the general partnership units were $0.2&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On September&nbsp;25, 2013, Navios Partners completed its public offering of 5,000,000 common units at $14.26 per unit and raised gross proceeds of $71.3
	million to fund its fleet expansion. The net proceeds of this offering, including the underwriting discount and excluding offering costs of $0.2 million were $68.2 million. Pursuant to this offering, Navios Partners issued 102,041 general
	partnership units to its general partner. The net proceeds from the issuance of the general partnership units were $1.5 million. On the same date, Navios Partners completed the exercise of the option previously granted to the underwriters in
	connection with the offering and issued 750,000 additional common units at the public offering price less the underwriting discount. As a result of the exercise of the option, Navios Partners raised additional gross proceeds of $10.7 million. The
	net proceeds, including the underwriting discount, were approximately $10.2 million&nbsp;and Navios Partners issued 15,306 additional general partnership units to its general partner. The net proceeds from the issuance of the general partnership
	units were $0.2 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;14, 2014, Navios Partners completed its public offering of 5,500,000 common units at $17.30 per unit and raised
	gross proceeds of approximately $95.2&nbsp;million to fund its fleet expansion. The net proceeds of this offering, including the underwriting discount and excluding offering costs estimated at $0.3&nbsp;million were approximately $91.1&nbsp;million.
	Pursuant to this offering, Navios Partners issued 112,245 general partnership units to its general partner. The net proceeds from the issuance of the general partnership units were $1.9&nbsp;million. On February&nbsp;18, 2014, Navios Partners
	completed the exercise of the option previously granted to the underwriters in connection with the offering and issued 825,000 additional common units at the public offering price less the underwriting discount. As a result of the exercise of the
	option, Navios Partners raised additional gross proceeds of $14.3&nbsp;million and net proceeds, including the underwriting discount, of approximately $13.7&nbsp;million and issued 16,837 additional general partnership units to its general partner.
	The net proceeds from the issuance of the general partnership units were $0.3&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On February&nbsp;11, 2015, Navios Partners completed its
	public offering of 4,000,000 common units at $13.09 per unit and raised gross proceeds of approximately $52.4 million&nbsp;to fund its fleet expansion. The net proceeds of this offering, including the underwriting discount and excluding offering
	costs of $0.2 million were approximately $50.1 million. Pursuant to this offering, Navios Partners issued 81,633 general partnership units to its general partner. The net proceeds from the issuance of the general partnership units were $1.1 million.
	On the same date, Navios Partners completed the exercise of the option previously granted to the underwriters in connection with the offering and issued 600,000 additional common units at the public offering price less the underwriting discount. As
	a result of the exercise of the option, Navios Partners raised additional gross proceeds of $7.9 million and net proceeds, including the underwriting discount, of approximately $7.5 million and issued 12,245 additional general partnership units to
	its general partner. The net proceeds from the issuance of the general partnership units were $0.2 million. In addition, Navios Partners completed a private placement of 1,120,547 common units and 22,868 general partner units at $13.09 per unit to
	Navios Holdings, raising additional gross proceeds of $15.0 million. Following the public offering and the private placement, Navios Holdings currently owns a 20.1% interest in Navios Partners, which includes the 2.0% interest through Navios
	Partners&#146; general partner which Navios Holdings owns and controls.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of March&nbsp;22, 2016, there were outstanding: 83,079,710 common units and
	1,695,509 general partnership units. During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, the aggregate amount of cash distribution paid was $132.3&nbsp;million, $139.0 million and $122.4&nbsp;million, respectively. In February 2016, we
	announced that our board of directors decided to suspend the quarterly cash distributions to our unitholders, including the distribution for the quarter ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. (See &#147;Suspension of Distributions&#148; contained herein).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	79
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Cash provided by operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 as compared to the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014:
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash provided by operating activities decreased by $48.3&nbsp;million to $123.4&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, as compared to $171.7&nbsp;million for the same period in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net income decreased by $33.0&nbsp;million to $41.8&nbsp;million
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, from $74.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. In determining net cash provided by operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, net income was adjusted for the effects
	of certain non-cash items, including $75.9&nbsp;million depreciation and amortization, $3.7&nbsp;million amortization and write-off of deferred financing costs and $4.0 million amortization of deferred drydock and special survey costs. For the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, net income was adjusted for the effects of certain non-cash items, including depreciation and amortization of $95.8&nbsp;million, $3.1&nbsp;million amortization and write-off of deferred financing cost and $0.8 million
	amortization of deferred dry dock and special survey costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Accounts receivable decreased by $9.3&nbsp;million, from $13.3&nbsp;million at
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, to $4.0 million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 due to the decrease in amounts due from charterers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Accounts payable decreased by
	$1.1&nbsp;million, from $3.8&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014, to $2.7 million at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Accrued expenses decreased by $1.1
	million from $3.6 million at December&nbsp;31, 2014, to $2.5 million at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Deferred revenue primarily relates to cash received from
	charterers prior to it being earned. Deferred revenue, net of commissions increased by $1.8&nbsp;million from $4.3&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014, to $6.1&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Amounts due to related parties increased by $6.8 million, from $1.9&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014, to $8.7&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
	The increase was mainly attributable to an increase in other payables for drydock and special survey expenses of $5.7 million and management fees outstanding of $1.2 million and other receivables of $1.8 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Payments for drydock and special survey costs incurred at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and December&nbsp;31, 2014 were $13.5&nbsp;million and $8.7&nbsp;million,
	respectively, and related to drydock and special survey costs incurred for certain vessels of the fleet.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	80
</P>

<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Cash used in investing activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 as compared to the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014:
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash used in investing activities increased by $26.1&nbsp;million to $149.3 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2015, as compared to $123.3 million&nbsp;for the same period in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash used in investing activities of $149.3&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 was due to: (i)&nbsp;$147.8&nbsp;million paid for the acquisition of the MSC Cristina, which was delivered in April&nbsp;2015; (ii)&nbsp;$0.8&nbsp;million loan granted to Navios Europe II; and (iii)&nbsp;$0.8 million used for
	investment in Navios Europe II.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash used in investing activities of $123.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was due to:
	(i)&nbsp;$36.9&nbsp;million paid for the acquisition of the Navios La Paix and the Navios Sun in January 2014&nbsp;of which $33.4 million was released from escrow; (ii)&nbsp;$5.9 million paid as deposits for the acquisition of a vessel which was
	delivered to Navios Partners in the fourth quarter of 2014; (iii)&nbsp;a $0.5 million loan granted to Navios Europe I; (iv)&nbsp;$59.1 million paid for the acquisition of the YM Utmost in August 2014; and (v)&nbsp;$59.1 million paid for the
	acquisition of the YM Unity in October 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Cash used in financing activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 as compared to cash provided
	by financing activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014:
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash used in financing activities decreased by $62.5&nbsp;million to
	$46.7&nbsp;million outflow for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, as compared to $15.8&nbsp;million inflow for the same period in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash used in
	financing activities of $46.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was due to: (i)&nbsp;$72.1&nbsp;million proceeds from the issuance of 4,600,000 common units in February 2015, net of offering costs; (ii)&nbsp;$1.5&nbsp;million
	proceeds from the issuance of additional general partnership units; and (iii)&nbsp;proceeds of $79.8&nbsp;million on April&nbsp;20, 2015, under the April 2015 Credit Facility. This overall increase was partially offset by: (i)&nbsp;loan repayments
	of $60.7&nbsp;million; (ii)&nbsp;payment of a total cash distribution of $132.3&nbsp;million; (iii)&nbsp;payment of $0.7 million of deferred financing costs relating to the April 2015 Credit Facility; and (iv)&nbsp;a $6.4 million increase in
	restricted cash related to the amounts held in retention accounts in order to service debt payments or as cash collateral, as required by Navios Partners&#146; credit facilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash provided by financing activities of $15.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was due to: (a)&nbsp;$104.5&nbsp;million of proceeds
	from the issuance of 6,325,000 common units in February 2014, net of offering costs; (b)&nbsp;$2.2&nbsp;million of proceeds from the issuance of additional general partnership units; and (c)&nbsp;proceeds of $56.0&nbsp;million under the
	September&nbsp;2014 Credit Facility. This overall increase was partially offset by: (a)&nbsp;loan repayments of $7.1&nbsp;million; (b)&nbsp;payment of a total cash distribution of $139.0&nbsp;million; and (c)&nbsp;payment of $0.9&nbsp;million of
	deferred financing costs relating to the September 2014 Credit Facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	81
