<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Cash provided by operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 as compared to the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2013:
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash provided by operating activities increased by $66.8&nbsp;million to $171.7&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, as compared to $104.8&nbsp;million for the same period in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net income increased by $15.8&nbsp;million to $74.9&nbsp;million
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, from $59.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, mainly due to: (i)&nbsp;compensation received from the sale of a defaulted counterparty claim to an unrelated third party; and
	(ii)&nbsp;compensation received following the termination of the amended credit default insurance policy. In determining net cash provided by operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, net income was adjusted for the effects of
	certain non-cash items, including depreciation and amortization of $95.8&nbsp;million, $3.1&nbsp;million amortization and write-off of deferred financing cost and $0.8 million amortization of deferred dry dock and special survey costs. For the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, net income was adjusted for the effects of certain non-cash items, including depreciation and amortization of $77.5&nbsp;million and $4.0&nbsp;million amortization and write-off of deferred financing cost.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Accounts receivable decreased by $3.0&nbsp;million, from $16.3&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2013, to $13.3 million at December&nbsp;31, 2014 due to the
	decrease in amounts due from charterers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Prepaid expenses and other current assets decreased by $0.2&nbsp;million, from $1.7&nbsp;million at
	December&nbsp;31, 2013, to $1.5&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Accounts payable increased by $0.7&nbsp;million, from $3.2&nbsp;million at
	December&nbsp;31, 2013, to $3.8 million at December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Accrued expenses decreased by $0.3&nbsp;million from $3.9&nbsp;million at
	December&nbsp;31, 2013 to $3.6 million at December&nbsp;31, 2014. The primary reason for the decrease was a decrease in accrued loan interest by $0.2 million and a decrease in accrued legal expenses by $0.7 million partially mitigated by an increase
	in accrued voyage expenses by $0.6 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Deferred revenue primarily relates to cash received from charterers prior to it being earned. Deferred
	revenue, net of commissions increased by $1.3&nbsp;million from $3.0&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2013 to $4.3&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Amounts due to related parties increased by $1.7 million, from $0.2&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2013, to $1.9&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014.
	The increase was mainly attributable to an increase in other payables for drydock and special survey expenses of $2.2 million mitigated by other receivables of $0.3 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	82
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage85"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Payment for drydock and special survey costs incurred in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 were
	$8.7&nbsp;million and related to drydock and special survey incurred for certain vessels of the fleet. There was no payment for drydock and special survey cost incurred in the same period of 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Cash used in investing activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013:
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash used in investing activities was $123.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 as compared to $382.7&nbsp;million for the same period
	in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash used in investing activities of $123.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was due to: (i)&nbsp;$36.9&nbsp;million paid
	for the acquisition of the Navios La Paix and the Navios Sun in January 2014&nbsp;of which $33.4 million was released from escrow; (ii)&nbsp;$5.9 million paid as deposits for the acquisition of a vessel which was delivered to Navios Partners in the
	fourth quarter of 2014; (iii)&nbsp;a $0.5 million loan granted to Navios Europe&nbsp;I; (iv)&nbsp;$59.1 million paid for the acquisition of the YM Utmost in August 2014; and (v)&nbsp;$59.1 million paid for the acquisition of the YM Unity in October
	2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash used in investing activities of $382.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 was due to: (i)&nbsp;$98.2&nbsp;million held in
	escrow for the acquisition of four vessels of which $47.0 million was released in September 2013 for the acquisition of the Navios Joy, $17.8 million was released in October 2013 for the acquisition of the Navios Harmony and $33.4 million was
	released in January 2014 to finance a portion of the purchase prices of the Navios Sun and the Navios La Paix, which were delivered in January 2014; (ii)&nbsp;$7.3&nbsp;million paid as deposits for the acquisition of the vessels that was delivered
	to Navios Partners in January 2014; (iii)&nbsp;a $0.3 million loan granted to Navios Europe I; (iv)&nbsp;$0.5 million for investment in Navios Europe I; and (v)&nbsp;$341.2 million paid for the acquisition of the Navios Joy on September&nbsp;11,
	2013, the acquisition of the Navios Harmony on October&nbsp;11, 2013 and the acquisition of five Container vessels in December 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Cash provided by
	financing activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013:
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net cash provided by financing
	activities decreased by $265.3&nbsp;million to $15.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, as compared to $281.0&nbsp;million for the same period in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash provided by financing activities of $15.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was due to: (a)&nbsp;$104.5&nbsp;million of proceeds
	from the issuance of 6,325,000 common units in February 2014, net of offering costs; (b)&nbsp;$2.2&nbsp;million of proceeds from the issuance of additional general partnership units; and (c)&nbsp;proceeds of $56.0&nbsp;million under the
	September&nbsp;2014 Credit Facility. This overall increase was partially offset by: (a)&nbsp;loan repayments of $7.1&nbsp;million; (b)&nbsp;payment of a total cash distribution of $139.0&nbsp;million; and (c)&nbsp;payment of $0.9&nbsp;million of
	deferred financing costs relating to the September 2014 Credit Facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash provided by financing activities of $281.0&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2013 was due to: (a)&nbsp;$148.0&nbsp;million of proceeds from the issuance of 10,925,000 common units in February 2013 and September 2013, net of offering costs; (b)&nbsp;$3.2&nbsp;million of proceeds from the issuance of
	additional general partnership units; (c)&nbsp;a&nbsp;$28.4 million decrease in restricted cash related to the amounts held in retention accounts in order to service debt as required by Navios Partners&#146; credit facilities; and (d)&nbsp;$434.5
	million of&nbsp;proceeds from the Term Loan B facility net of discount. This overall increase was partially mitigated by: (a)&nbsp;loan repayments and prepayment of long-term debt, net of expenses, of $201.4&nbsp;million; (b)&nbsp;payment of a total
	cash distribution of $122.4&nbsp;million; and (c)&nbsp;payment of $9.2 million of deferred financing cost relating to the July 2012 Credit Facility and the Term Loan&nbsp;B facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	83
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	EBITDA
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	EBITDA represents
	net income plus interest and finance costs plus depreciation and amortization and income taxes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	EBITDA is presented because Navios Partners believes that
	EBITDA is a basis upon which liquidity can be assessed and present useful information to investors regarding Navios Partners&#146; ability to service and/or incur indebtedness, pay capital expenditures, meet working capital requirements and pay
	dividends. EBITDA is a &#147;non-GAAP financial measure&#148; and should not be considered a substitute for net income, cash flow from operating activities and other operations or cash flow statement data prepared in accordance with accounting
	principles generally accepted in the United States or as a measure of profitability or liquidity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	While EBITDA is frequently used as a measure of
	operating results and the ability to meet debt service requirements, the definition of EBITDA used here may not be comparable to that used by other companies due to differences in methods of calculation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	EBITDA decreased by $46.7&nbsp;million to $153.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, as compared to $200.0&nbsp;million for the same
	period in 2014. The decrease in EBITDA was due to: (i)&nbsp;a $3.7 million decrease in revenue; (ii)&nbsp;a $6.2 million increase in management fees; (iii)&nbsp;a $0.1 million increase in general and administrative expenses due to the increased
	fleet; (iv)&nbsp;a $42.7 million decrease in other income; and (v)&nbsp;a $2.3&nbsp;million increase in other expenses. The above decrease was partially mitigated by an $8.2 million decrease in time charter and voyage expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	84
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage87"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	EBITDA increased by $46.6&nbsp;million to $200.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, as
	compared to $153.4&nbsp;million for the same period in 2013. The increase in EBITDA was due to: (i)&nbsp;a $29.2 million increase in revenue; and (ii)&nbsp;a $34.2 million increase in other income due to compensation received following the
	termination of the credit default insurance policy. The above increase was partially mitigated by: (a)&nbsp;a $14.2&nbsp;million increase in management fees and (b)&nbsp;a $1.5 million increase in general and administrative expenses due to the
	increased fleet; (c)&nbsp;a $0.5 million increase in time charter and voyage expenses; and (d)&nbsp;a $0.7 million increase in other expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Operating Surplus
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Operating Surplus represents net
	income adjusted for depreciation and amortization expense, non-cash interest expense and estimated maintenance and replacement capital expenditures. Maintenance and replacement capital expenditures are those capital expenditures, estimated by the
	board of directors to be required to maintain over the long term the operating capacity of, or the revenue generated by, Navios Partners&#146; capital assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Operating Surplus is a quantitative measure used in the publicly-traded partnership investment community to assist in evaluating a partnership&#146;s ability
	to make quarterly cash distributions. Operating Surplus is not required by accounting principles generally accepted in the United States and should not be considered a substitute for net income, cash flow from operating activities and other
	operations or cash flow statement data prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States or as a measure of profitability or liquidity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Borrowings
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Navios Partners&#146; long-term third party
	borrowings are reflected in its balance sheet as &#147;Long-term debt, net&#148; and &#147;Current portion of long-term debt, net&#148;. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and December&nbsp;31, 2014, total debt, net amounted to $598.1&nbsp;million and
	$576.0&nbsp;million, respectively. The current portion of long-term debt, net amounted to $23.3 million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and $16.4&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Capital Expenditures
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, we financed our capital expenditures with cash flow from operations, the incurrence of bank debt and equity raisings. Capital expenditures for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 amounted to
	$147.8&nbsp;million, $122.8&nbsp;million and $381.9&nbsp;million, respectively. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, expansion capital expenditures of $147.8&nbsp;million related to the acquisition of the MSC Cristina in April 2015. For the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, expansion capital expenditures of $122.8&nbsp;million related to the acquisition of the Navios La Paix and the Navios Sun in January 2014, the acquisition of the YM Utmost in August 2014 and the acquisition of the
	YM Unity in October 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Maintenance for our vessels and expenses related to drydocking expenses are reimbursed at cost by Navios Partners to our
	Manager under the amended management agreement. In October&nbsp;2011, Navios Partners extended the duration of its existing Management Agreement with the Manager until December&nbsp;31, 2017 and fixed the rate for shipmanagement services of its
	owned fleet through December&nbsp;31, 2013. The management fees, including drydocking expenses, were: (a)&nbsp;$4,650 daily rate per Ultra-Handymax vessel; (b)&nbsp;$4,550 daily rate per Panamax vessel; and (c)&nbsp;$5,650 daily rate per Capesize
	vessel. In each of October 2013,&nbsp;August 2014,&nbsp;February 2015 and February 2016, Navios&nbsp;Partners amended its existing Management Agreement with the Manager to fix the fees for ship management services of its owned fleet, excluding
	drydocking expenses, which are reimbursed at cost by Navios Partners at: (a)&nbsp;$4,100 daily rate per Ultra-Handymax vessel; (b)&nbsp;$4,200 daily rate per Panamax vessel; (c)&nbsp;$5,250 daily rate per Capesize vessel; (d)&nbsp;$6,700 daily rate
	per Container vessel of TEU 6,800; (e)&nbsp;$7,400&nbsp;daily rate per Container vessel of more than TEU 8,000; and (f)&nbsp;$8,750 daily rate per very large Container vessel of more than TEU 13,000 through December&nbsp;31, 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	85
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage88"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Maintenance and Replacement Capital Expenditures Reserve
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our annual maintenance and replacement capital expenditures reserve for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 was $13.8&nbsp;million and
	$24.0&nbsp;million, respectively, for replacing our vessels at the end of their useful lives.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The amount for estimated replacement capital expenditures
	attributable to future vessel replacement was based&nbsp;on the following assumptions: (i)&nbsp;current market price to purchase a five year old vessel of similar size and specifications; (ii)&nbsp;a&nbsp;25-year useful life for drybulk vessels and
	a&nbsp;30-year useful life for container vessels; and (iii)&nbsp;a relative net investment rate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The amount for estimated maintenance capital
	expenditures attributable to future vessel drydocking and special survey was based on certain assumptions including the remaining useful life of the owned vessels of our fleet, market costs of drydocking and special survey and a relative net
	investment rate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our Board of Directors, with the approval of the conflicts committee, may determine that one or more of our assumptions should be
	revised, which could cause our Board of Directors to increase or decrease the amount of estimated maintenance and replacement capital expenditures. The actual cost of replacing the vessels in our fleet will depend on a number of factors, including
	prevailing market conditions, charter hire rates and the availability and cost of financing at the time of replacement. We may elect to finance some or all of our maintenance and replacement capital expenditures through the issuance of additional
	common units which could be dilutive to existing unitholders.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Possible Acquisitions of Other Vessels
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Although we do not currently have in place any other agreements relating to acquisitions of other vessels, we assess potential acquisition opportunities on a
	regular basis. Pursuant to our Omnibus Agreement with Navios Holdings, as amended in June 2009, we will have the opportunity to purchase additional drybulk vessels from Navios Holdings when those vessels are fixed under charters of three or more
	years upon their expiration of their current charters or upon completion of their construction. Subject to the terms of our loan agreements, we could elect to fund any future acquisitions with equity or debt or cash on hand or a combination of these
	forms of consideration. Any debt incurred for this purpose could make us more leveraged and increase our debt service obligations or could subject us to additional operational or financial restrictive covenants.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	C. Research and development, patents and licenses, etc.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Not applicable.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	D. Trend information
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our results of operations depend primarily on the charter hire rates that we are able to realize for our vessels, which depend on the demand and supply
	dynamics characterizing the drybulk market at any given time. For other trends affecting our business please see other discussions in &#147;Item 5&#151;Operating and Financial Review and Prospects&#148;.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	E. Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have no off-balance
	sheet arrangements that have or are reasonably likely to have, a current or future material effect on our financial condition, changes in financial condition, revenues or expenses, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditures or capital
	resources.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	86
</P>

	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Represents principal payments on amounts drawn on our credit facilities that bear interest at applicable fixed interest rates ranging from 1.80% to 4.25% plus LIBOR&nbsp;per annum. The amounts in the table exclude
	expected interest payments of $27.2 million (less than 1 year), $28.8 million (1-3 years), $25.8&nbsp;million
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(3-5&nbsp;years)
</FONT>
	and $1.8 million (more than 5 years). Expected interest payments are based on
	outstanding principal amounts, applicable currently effective interest rates and margins as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, timing of scheduled payments and the term of the debt obligations.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Navios Holdings, Navios Acquisition and Navios Partners will make available to Navios Europe I (in each case, in proportion to their ownership interests in
	Navios Europe I) revolving loans up to $24.1 million to fund working capital requirements (collectively, the &#147;Navios Revolving Loans I&#148;). As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the amounts undrawn from the Navios Revolving Loans I were $9.1
	million, of which Navios Partners&#146; portion was $0.5 million (See Note 17 for Transactions with related parties and affiliates).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Navios Holdings,
	Navios Acquisition and Navios Partners will make available to Navios Europe II (in each case, in proportion to their ownership interests in Navios Europe II) revolving loans up to $38.5 million to fund working capital requirements (collectively, the
	&#147;Navios Revolving Loans II&#148;). As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the amounts undrawn from the Navios Revolving Loans II were $23.1 million, of which Navios Partners&#146; portion was $1.2 million (See Note 17 for Transactions with related
	parties and affiliates).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Critical Accounting Policies
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our financial statements have been prepared in accordance with US GAAP. The preparation of these financial statements requires us to make estimates in the
	application of our accounting policies based on the best assumptions, judgments and opinions of management. Following is a discussion of the accounting policies that involve a higher degree of judgment and the methods of their application that
	affect the reported amount of assets and liabilities, revenues and expenses and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of our financial statements. Actual results may differ from these estimates under different
	assumptions or conditions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Critical accounting policies are those that reflect significant judgments or uncertainties, and potentially result in
	materially different results under different assumptions and conditions. For a description of all of our significant accounting policies, see Note&nbsp;2 to the Notes to the consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, Navios Partners owned a fleet of 31 vessels, with an aggregate carrying value of $1,285.6 million, including the carrying
	value of existing time charters on its fleet of vessels. On a vessel-by-vessel basis, as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the carrying value of 28 of Navios Partners&#146; vessels (including the carrying value of the time charter, if any, on the specified
	vessel) exceeded the estimated fair value of those same vessels (including the estimated fair value of the time charter, if any, on the specified vessel) by approximately $319.5 million in the aggregate (the unrealized loss).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	87
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage90"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

	A vessel-by-vessel summary as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, follows (with an * indicating those individual vessels
	whose carrying value exceeds its estimated fair value, including the related time charter, if any):
</P>

	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	All amounts include related time charter, if any. Although the aforementioned excess of carrying value over fair value represents an estimate of the loss that Navios Partners would sustain on a hypothetical disposition
	of those vessels as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the recognition of the unrealized loss absent a disposition (i.e., as an impairment) would require, among other things, that a triggering event had occurred and that the undiscounted cash flows
	attributable to the vessel are also less than the carrying value of the vessel (including the carrying value of the time charter, if any, on the specified vessel).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Impairment of Long Lived Assets
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Vessels, other fixed
	assets and other long lived assets held and used by Navios Partners are reviewed periodically for potential impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of a
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	88
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage91"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	particular asset may not be fully recoverable. In accordance with accounting for the &#147;impairment or disposal of long-lived assets&#148;, Navios Partners&#146; management evaluates the
	carrying amounts and periods over which long-lived assets are depreciated to determine if events or changes in circumstances have occurred that would require modification to their carrying values or useful lives. In evaluating useful lives and
	carrying values of long-lived assets, certain indicators of potential impairment, are reviewed such as undiscounted projected operating cash flows, vessel sales and purchases, business plans and overall market conditions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Undiscounted projected net operating cash flows are determined for each vessel and compared to the vessel carrying value of the vessel and related carrying
	value of the intangible with respect to the time charter agreement attached to that vessel. Within the shipping industry, vessels are customarily bought and sold with a charter attached. The value of the charter may be favorable or unfavorable when
	comparing the charter rate to then current market rates. The loss recognized either on impairment (or on disposition) will reflect the excess of carrying value over fair value (selling price) for the vessel asset group.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015, management concluded that events occurred and circumstances had changed, which indicated that potential impairment
	of Navios Partners&#146; long-lived assets may exist. These indicators included continued deterioration in the spot market, and the related, impact of the current drybulk and container sector has on management&#146;s expectation for future revenues.
	As a result, an impairment assessment of long-lived assets was performed.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Navios Partners determined undiscounted projected net operating cash flows for
	each vessel and compared it to the vessel&#146;s carrying value together with the carrying value of deferred drydock and special survey costs related to the vessel and the carrying value of the related intangible. The significant factors and
	assumptions used in the undiscounted projected net operating cash flow analysis included: determining the projected net operating cash flows by considering the charter revenues from existing time charters for the fixed fleet days (Navios
	Partners&#146; remaining charter agreement rates) and an estimated daily time charter equivalent for the unfixed days (based on a combination of the Navios Partners&#146; remaining charter agreement rates and the 10-year average historical one year
	time charter rates adjusted for outliers) over the remaining economic life of each vessel, net of brokerage and address commissions and excluding days of scheduled off-hires, management fees fixed until December 2015 and thereafter assuming an
	annual increase of 3.0% and utilization rate of 98.6% based on the fleet&#146;s historical performance. The assessment concluded that step two of the impairment analysis was not required and no impairment of vessels and the intangible assets existed
	as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, as the undiscounted projected net operating cash flows exceeded the carrying value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In connection with its annual
	impairment testing on its vessels as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company performs sensitivity analysis on the most sensitive and/or subjective assumptions that have the potential to affect the outcome of the test, principally the projected
	charter rate used to forecast future cash flows for unfixed days. In that regard, there would continue to be no impairment required to be recognized on any of the Company&#146;s vessels when assuming a decline in the 10-year average (of the one-year
	charter rate for similar vessels), which is the rate that the Company uses to forecast future cash flows for unfixed days, ranging from 13.17% to 90.73% (depending on the vessel).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	89
</P>

	In addition, the Company compared the ten-year historical average (of the one-year charter rate for similar
	vessels), with current rates for five-year, three-year and one-year charters (for similar vessels). A comparison of the ten-year historical average (of the one-year charter rate) and the current rates for five-year, three-year and one-year charters
	(for similar vessels) follows (as of December&nbsp;31, 2015):

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	*
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	For the vessels with capacity of 6,800 TEU, 8,200 TEU and 13,100 TEU and above, the average daily rates were only available for the years 2013, 2014 and 2015.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As disclosed elsewhere, the Company&#146;s fleet includes 28 vessels for which the carrying value (including the carrying value of the time charter, if any,
	on the specified vessel) exceeds the estimated fair value of those same vessels (including the estimated fair value of the time charter, if any, on the specified vessel) by approximately $319.5 million in the aggregate (the unrealized loss). If
	testing for impairment using current rates for five-year, three-year and one-year charters historical average (of the one-year charter rate for similar vessels) in lieu of the ten-year historical average (of the one-year charter rate for similar
	vessels), Navios Partners estimates that an additional one, five and one of its vessels, respectively, would have carrying values in excess of their projected undiscounted future cash flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the 10-year historical average rates for its vessels (which naturally varies by type of vessel) used in determining future cash
	flows for purposes of its impairment analysis were less than 5% higher than the Company&#146;s average daily time charter equivalent rate achieved in fiscal year 2015 of $19,739 per day.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In the event that impairment would occur, the fair value of the related asset would be determined and an impairment charge would be recorded to operations
	calculated by comparing the asset&#146;s carrying value to its fair value. Fair value is estimated primarily through the use of third-party valuations performed on an individual vessel basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Although management believes the underlying assumptions supporting this assessment are reasonable, if charter rate trends and the length of the current market
	downturn vary significantly from our forecasts, management may be required to perform step two of the impairment analysis in the future that could expose Navios Partners to material impairment charges in the future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	No impairment loss was recognized for any of the periods presented.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Vessels
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Vessels are stated at historical cost, which
	consists of the contract price and any material expenses incurred upon acquisition (improvements and delivery expenses). Vessels acquired in an asset acquisition or in business combination are recorded at fair value. Subsequent expenditures for
	major improvements and upgrading are capitalized, provided they appreciably extend the life, increase the earning capacity or improve the efficiency or safety of the vessels. Expenditures for routine maintenance and repairs are expensed as incurred.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	90
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage93"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Depreciation is computed using the straight line method over the useful life of the vessels, after considering
	the estimated residual value. Management estimates the residual values of our drybulk and container vessels based on a scrap value of $340 per lightweight ton, as we believe these levels are consistent with those of similar companies within the
	shipping industry. Management estimates the useful life of our vessels to be 25 and 30&nbsp;years from the drybulk and container vessel&#146;s original construction, respectively. However, when regulations place limitations over the ability of a
	vessel to trade on a worldwide basis, its useful life is re-estimated to end at the date such regulations become effective.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Deferred Drydock and
	Special Survey Costs
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our vessels are subject to regularly scheduled dry docking and special surveys which are carried out every 30 or 60 months to
	coincide with the renewal of the related certificates issued by the classification societies, unless a further extension is obtained in rare cases and under certain conditions. In each of October 2013,&nbsp;August 2014,&nbsp;February 2015 and
	February 2016, Navios&nbsp;Partners amended its existing management agreement with the Manager to fix the fees for ship management services of its owned fleet (excluding drydocking expenses which are reimbursed at cost by Navios Partners) at:
	(a)&nbsp;$4,100 daily rate per Ultra-Handymax vessel; (b)&nbsp;$4,200 daily rate per Panamax vessel; (c)&nbsp;$5,250 daily rate per Capesize vessel; (d)&nbsp;$6,700 daily rate per Container vessel of TEU 6,800; (e)&nbsp;$7,400 daily rate per
	Container vessel of more than TEU 8,000; and (f)&nbsp;$8,750 daily rate per very large Container vessel of more than TEU 13,000 through December&nbsp;31, 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Revenue Recognition
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue is recorded when services
	are rendered, under a signed charter agreement or other evidence of an arrangement, the price is fixed or determinable, and collection is reasonably assured. Revenue is generated from time charter of vessels.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Voyage revenues for the transportation of cargo are recognized ratably over the estimated relative transit time of each voyage. Voyage expenses are recognized
	as incurred. A voyage is deemed to commence when a vessel is available for loading and is deemed to end upon the completion of the discharge of the current cargo. Estimated losses on voyages are provided for in full at the time such losses become
	evident. Under a voyage charter, a vessel is provided for the transportation of specific goods between specific ports in return for payment of an agreed upon freight per ton of cargo.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenues from time chartering of vessels are accounted for as operating leases and are thus recognized on a straight line basis as the average minimum lease
	revenue over the rental periods of such charter agreements, as service is performed. A time charter involves placing a vessel at the charterers&#146; disposal for a period of time during which the charterer uses the vessel in return for the payment
	of a specified daily hire rate. Under time charters, operating costs such as for crews, maintenance and insurance are typically paid by the owner of the vessel.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenues from profit-sharing are calculated at an agreed percentage of the excess of the charterer&#146;s average daily income over an agreed amount and
	accounted for on an accrual basis based on provisional amounts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenues are recorded net of address commissions. Address commissions represent a
	discount provided directly to the charterers based on a fixed percentage of the agreed upon charter rate. Since address commissions represent a discount (sales incentive) on services rendered by Navios Partners and no identifiable benefit is
	received in exchange for the consideration provided to the charterer, these commissions are presented as a reduction of revenue.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Recent Accounting
	Pronouncements
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In February 2016, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No.&nbsp;2016-02, &#147;Leases (Topic 842)&#148;
	(&#147;ASU&nbsp;2016-02&#148;). ASU 2016-02 will apply to both types of leases &#151; capital (or finance) leases and operating leases. According to the new Accounting Standard, lessees will be required to recognize assets and liabilities on
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	91
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage94"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	the balance sheet for the rights and obligations created by all leases with terms of more than 12 months. ASU&nbsp;2016-02 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2018,
	including interim periods within those fiscal years. Early application is permitted. The Company is currently assessing the impact that adopting this new accounting guidance will have on its consolidated financial statements and footnotes
	disclosures.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In February 2015, the FASB issued the ASU 2015-02, &#147;Consolidation (Topic 810)&#151;Amendments to the Consolidation Analysis&#148;,
	which amends the criteria for determining which entities are considered VIEs, amends the criteria for determining if a service provider possesses a variable interest in a VIE and ends the deferral granted to investment companies for application of
	the VIE consolidation model. The ASU is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2015. Early application is permitted. We do not expect the adoption of this ASU to have a material impact on the Company&#146;s
	results of operations, financial position or cash flows, except if Navios Partners were to enter into new arrangements in 2015 that fall into the scope prior to adoption of this standard.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In January 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-01, Income Statement Extraordinary and Unusual Items. This standard eliminates the concept of extraordinary and
	unusual items from U.S. GAAP. The new standard is effective for annual and interim periods after December&nbsp;15, 2015. Early adoption is permitted. Navios Partners plans to adopt this standard effective January&nbsp;1, 2016. The adoption of the
	new standard is not expected to have a material impact on Navios Partners&#146; results of operations, financial position or cash flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In August 2014,
	the FASB issued ASU No.&nbsp;2014-15, Presentation of Financial Statements-Going Concern (Subtopic 205-40): Disclosure of Uncertainties About an Entity&#146;s Ability to Continue as a Going Concern. This standard requires management to assess an
	entity&#146;s ability to continue as a going concern, and to provide related footnote disclosures in certain circumstances. Before this new standard, no accounting guidance existed for management on when and how to assess or disclose going concern
	uncertainties. The amendments are effective for annual periods ending after December&nbsp;15, 2016, and interim periods within annual periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2016. Early application is permitted. We plan to adopt this standard
	effective January&nbsp;1, 2017. The adoption of the new standard is not expected to have a material impact on Navios Partners&#146; results of operations, financial position or cash flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers, clarifying the method used to determine the timing and requirements for
	revenue recognition on the statements of income. Under the new standard, an entity must identify the performance obligations in a contract, the transaction price and allocate the price to specific performance obligations to recognize the revenue
	when the obligation is completed. The amendments in this update also require disclosure of sufficient information to allow users to understand the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flow arising from contracts. The new
	accounting guidance is effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2016. Early adoption is not permitted. We are currently reviewing the effect of ASU No.&nbsp;2014-09 on our revenue recognition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In April 2014, the FASB issued ASU 2014-08, Presentation of Financial Statements and Property, Plant and Equipment changing the presentation of discontinued
	operations on the statements of income and other requirements for reporting discontinued operations. Under the new standard, a disposal of a component or a group of components of an entity is required to be reported in discontinued operations if the
	disposal represents a strategic shift that has (or will have) a major effect on an entity&#146;s operations and financial results when the component meets the criteria to be classified as held-for-sale or is disposed. The amendments in this update
	also require additional disclosures about discontinued operations and disposal of an individually significant component of an entity that does not qualify for discontinued operations. The new accounting guidance is effective for interim and annual
	periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2014. The adoption of the new standard is not expected to have a material impact on Navios Partners&#146; results of operations, financial position or cash flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	92
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Biographical information with respect to each of our current directors and our executive officers is set forth below. The
	business address for our directors and executive officers is 7 Avenue de Grande Bretagne, Monte Carlo, MC 98000 Monaco.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Angeliki Frangou
</B>
	has been
	our Chairman and CEO since August 2007. In addition, Ms.&nbsp;Frangou has been the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Navios Holdings (NYSE: NM), our sponsor, since August 2005, and the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Navios Acquisition
	(NYSE: NNA), an affiliated corporation, since 2008 and the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Navios Midstream (NYSE: NAP), an affiliated limited partnership since October 2014. Ms.&nbsp;Frangou has been the Chairman of the Board of Directors
	of Navios South American Logistics Inc. since its inception in December 2007. Previously, Ms.&nbsp;Frangou served as Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President of International Shipping Enterprises Inc., which acquired Navios Holdings. From
	1990 until August 2005, Ms.&nbsp;Frangou was the Chief Executive Officer of Maritime Enterprises Management S.A. and its predecessor company, which specialized in the management of dry cargo vessels. Ms.&nbsp;Frangou is the Chairman of IRF European
	Finance Investments Ltd., listed on the SFM of the London Stock Exchange. Ms.&nbsp;Frangou is Member of the Board of the United Kingdom Mutual Steam Ship Assurance Association (Bermuda) Limited, Vice Chairman of China Classification Society
	Mediterranean Committee, a member of the International General Committee and of the Hellenic and Black Sea Committee of Bureau Veritas, as well as a member of Greek Committee of Nippon Kaiji Kyokai. Since February 2015, Ms.&nbsp;Frangou is a Member
	of the Board of the Union of Greek Shipowners. Since October 2015, Ms.&nbsp;Frangou has been a Member of the Board of Trustees of Fairleigh Dickinson University. Since July 2013, Ms.&nbsp;Frangou has been a Member of the Board of Visitors of the
	Columbia University School of Engineering and Applied Science. Ms.&nbsp;Frangou received a bachelor&#146;s degree in mechanical engineering,
<I>
	summa cum laude
</I>
	, from Fairleigh Dickinson University and a master&#146;s degree in mechanical
	engineering from Columbia University.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Stratos Desypris
</B>
	is Chief Financial Officer of Navios Maritime Partners L.P. since January 2010. In addition
	Mr.&nbsp;Desypris is the Chief Financial Controller of Navios Holdings, Navios Partners&#146; sponsor, since May 2006. Mr.&nbsp;Desypris is also a Director and Senior Vice President &#150; Business Development of Navios Midstream since October 2014.
	He also serves as a Director and the SVP- Strategic Planning of Navios South American Logistics Inc and as a Director in Navios Europe. Before joining Navios Group, Mr.&nbsp;Desypris worked for 9&nbsp;years in the accounting profession, most
	recently as manager of the audit department at Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young in Greece. Mr.&nbsp;Desypris started his career as an auditor with Arthur Andersen&nbsp;&amp; Co. in 1997. He holds a Bachelor of Science degree in Economics from the University
	of Piraeus.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	George Achniotis
</B>
	was appointed to our Board of Directors in August 2007 and he has been our Executive Vice President-Business
	Development since February 2008. Mr.&nbsp;Achniotis has been Navios Holdings&#146; Chief Financial Officer since April&nbsp;12, 2007. Prior to being appointed Chief Financial Officer of Navios Holdings, Mr.&nbsp;Achniotis
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	93
</P>

<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	served as Senior Vice President&nbsp;&#151; Business Development of Navios Holdings from August 2006 to April 2007. Prior to joining Navios Holdings, Mr.&nbsp;Achniotis was a partner at
	PricewaterhouseCoopers from 1999 to August 2006. Mr.&nbsp;Achniotis holds a Bachelors of Science degree in engineering from the University of Manchester and he is a member of the institute of chartered accountants in England and Wales.
	Mr.&nbsp;Achniotis is also a member of the institute of certified accountants in Cyprus.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Shunji Sasada
</B>
	was appointed to our Board of Directors in
	August 2007. Mr.&nbsp;Sasada also served as a director of Navios Holdings and President of Navios Corporation since January 2015, as director in Navios Maritime Midstream Partners L.P. since October 2014. Mr.&nbsp;Sasada started his shipping career
	in 1981 in Japan with Mitsui O.S.K. Lines, Ltd. (&#147;MOSK&#148;). In 1991, Mr.&nbsp;Sasada joined Trinity Bulk Carriers as its chartering manager as well as subsidiary board member representing MOSK as one of the shareholders. After an assignment
	in Norway, Mr.&nbsp;Sasada moved to London and started MOSK&#146;s own Ultra Handymax operation as its General Manager. Mr.&nbsp;Sasada joined Navios Holdings in May 1997. Mr.&nbsp;Sasada was Senior Vice President&nbsp;&#151; Fleet Development of
	Navios Holdings from October&nbsp;1, 2005 to July 2007 and Chief Operating Officer to December 2014. Mr.&nbsp;Sasada is the member of the North American Committee of Nippon Kaiji Kyokai since inception. Mr.&nbsp;Sasada is a graduate of Keio
	University, Tokyo, with a B.A. degree in business and he is the member of Board of Trustee of Keio Academy of New York.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Serafeim
	Kriempardis
</B>
	&nbsp;was appointed to our Board of Directors in December 2009. Mr.&nbsp;Kriempardis previously served as the Head of Shipping of Piraeus Bank from 2007 to 2009 and as the Head of Shipping of Emporiki Bank of Greece from 1999 to 2007.
	Prior to serving as Head of Shipping at Emporiki Bank, Mr.&nbsp;Kriempardis served in the Project Finance and Corporate and Feasibility departments of the bank. Mr.&nbsp;Kriempardis is an accountant by training and holds a Bachelor&#146;s degree in
	Economics from the Athens University of Economics and Business and a Diploma in Management from the McGill University of Canada.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Robert Pierot
</B>
	was
	appointed to our Board of Directors in October 2007. Since 1979, Mr.&nbsp;Pierot has been engaged in brokering the sale and purchase of a variety of marine assets ranging from U.S. flag inland waterway marine assets, both United States and
	non-United States flagged vessels ranging from large bulk carriers, tankers, container vessels, U.S. inland waterway equipment and vessels that are used to service the offshore oil and gas exploration and production facilities. Currently,
	Mr.&nbsp;Pierot serves as director and principal of Jacq. Pierot Jr.&nbsp;&amp; Sons, Inc., a privately held shipbrokers firm based in New York. Mr.&nbsp;Pierot served as a board member for Chiles Offshore prior to its sale to another U.S. publicly
	traded offshore drilling rig company. Previously, Mr.&nbsp;Pierothas served asa member of the United States Department of Transportation&#146;s Shipbuilding Subcommittee, the Marine Transportation System National Advisory Council. Since 1980,
	Mr.&nbsp;Pierot has been a member of the Board of Directors of the Hellenic-American Chamber of Commerce and previously served as Chairman of the Board from mid 2011 to mid 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	John Karakadas
</B>
	&nbsp;was appointed to our Board of Directors in October 2007. Mr.&nbsp;Karakadas is the founder and Senior Managing Partner of AESION
	LLC, an investment management company, based in Greenwich, CT. From 2005 to 2011, Mr.&nbsp;Karakadas has served as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of SingularLogic, an European software vendor and information technology services provider listed
	on the Athens Exchange. In parallel, from April 2007 until 2009, Mr.&nbsp;Karakadas has served as Executive Director and Deputy CEO of Marfin Investment Group, an Athens Exchange listed Investment Company In 2011, from the position of Executive
	Chairman of the Board of Directors of Olympic Air, he led the successful turnaround process following its privatization. Also, since 2004, he has served on the Board of Directors of Greek Information Technology Holdings S.A. During the period
	between 2002 and 2003, Mr.&nbsp;Karakadas was the CEO of Tchibo GmbH. Prior to that time, from 1999 to 2000, Mr.&nbsp;Karakadas was President, Asia Pacific, of Burger King, based in&nbsp;Sydney,&nbsp;Australia. Mr.&nbsp;Karakadas received a B.B.A.
	in Industrial Management from&nbsp;Kent&nbsp;State University. Mr.&nbsp;Karakadas also serves on our Audit Committee and is an independent director.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Dimitris Papastefanou Gkouras
</B>
	&nbsp;was appointed to our Board of Directors in June&nbsp;2013. From 2007 until 2012, Mr.&nbsp;Papastefanou Gkouras
	served as Credit Director of Shipping for Marfin Egnatia Bank as well as a member of
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	94
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage97"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	the bank&#146;s Greek and International Credit Committees.&nbsp;Prior to his position with Marfin Egnatia Bank, Mr.&nbsp;Papastefanou Gkouras served in various managing and advisory roles within
	the corporate and shipping finance sectors, including stints with Greek and other European banks, including Credit Commercial de France.&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Papastefanou Gkouras received a B.A. in Economics and History from American College of
	Greece&#150;Deree in Athens, Greece and a diploma in Economic Analysis from&nbsp;the University of Kent, England.&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Papastefanou Gkouras also serves on our Audit Committee and is an independent director.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Vasiliki Papaefthymiou
</B>
	was appointed our Secretary in August 2007. Ms.&nbsp;Papaefthymiou has been Executive Vice President&nbsp;&#151; Legal and a
	member of Navios Holdings&#146; board of directors since August&nbsp;25, 2005, and prior to that was a member of the board of directors of ISE. Ms.&nbsp;Papaefthymiou has served as general counsel for Maritime Enterprises Management S.A. since
	October 2001, where she has advised the company on shipping, corporate and finance legal matters. Ms.&nbsp;Papaefthymiou provided similar services as general counsel to Franser Shipping from October 1991 to September 2001. Ms.&nbsp;Papaefthymiou
	received her undergraduate degree from the Law School of the University of Athens and a Master degree in Maritime Law from Southampton University in the United Kingdom. Ms.&nbsp;Papaefthymiou is admitted to practice law before the Bar in Piraeus,
	Greece.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	B. Compensation
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Reimbursement of
	Expenses of Our General Partner
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our General Partner does not receive any management fee or other compensation for services from us, although it will
	be entitled to reimbursement for expenses incurred on our behalf. In addition, we reimburse the Manager and certain affiliates for expenses incurred pursuant to the Management Agreement and Administrative Services Agreement we entered into with the
	Manager. Our General Partner and its other affiliates are reimbursed for expenses incurred on our behalf. These expenses include all expenses necessary or appropriate for the conduct of our business and allocable to us, as determined by our General
	Partner. For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 no amounts were paid to the General Partner.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Officers&#146; Compensation
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We and our General Partner were formed in August 2007. Because our officers, including our Chief Executive Officer and our Chief Financial Officer, are
	employees of Navios Holdings, their compensation is set and paid by Navios Holdings, and we reimburse Navios Holdings for time they spend on partnership matters pursuant to the administrative services agreement. Under the terms of the administrative
	agreement, we reimburse Navios Holdings for the actual costs and expenses it incurs in providing administrative support services to us. The amount of our reimbursements to Navios Holdings for the time of our officers depends on an estimate of the
	percentage of time our officers spent on our business and is based on a percentage of the salary and benefits that Navios Holdings pays to such officers. Our officers, and officers and employees of affiliates of our General Partner, may participate
	in employee benefit plans and arrangements sponsored by Navios Holdings, our General Partner or their affiliates, including plans that may be established in the future. Our board of directors may establish such plans without the approval of our
	limited partners. For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, the fee charged by the Manager for administrative services was $6.2&nbsp;million, $6.1&nbsp;million and $4.4&nbsp;million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Compensation of Directors
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our officers or officers of
	Navios Holdings who also serve as our directors do not receive additional compensation for their service as directors. Each non-management director receives compensation for attending meetings of our board of directors, as well as committee
	meetings. Non-management directors receive a director fee of $45,000 per year. Ms.&nbsp;Frangou receives a fee of $150,000 per year for acting as a director and as our Chairman of the Board. The Chairman of our audit committee and our conflicts
	committee receives an additional fee of $20,000 per year. In addition, each director is reimbursed for out-of-pocket expenses in connection with
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	95
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage98"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	attending meetings of the board of directors or committees. Each director is fully indemnified by us for actions associated with being a director to the extent permitted under Marshall Islands
	law.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For each of the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, aggregate annual compensation paid to our current non-management executive
	directors was $0.2 million and $0.15 million was paid to Ms.&nbsp;Frangou for acting as a director and as our Chairman of the Board.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	C. Board
	Practices
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our partnership agreement provides that our General Partner has delegated to our board of directors the authority to oversee and direct our
	operations, management and policies on an exclusive basis and such delegation will be binding on any successor general partner of the partnership. Our General Partner, Navios GP L.L.C., is wholly owned by Navios Holdings. Our executive officers
	manage our day-to-day activities consistent with the policies and procedures adopted by our board of directors. All of our executive officers and three of our directors also are executive officers, directors and/or affiliates of Navios Holdings and
	our Chief Executive Officer is also the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Navios Acquisition and Navios Holdings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Following our first annual
	meeting of unitholders in 2008, our board of directors consisted of seven members, three persons who were appointed by our General Partner in its sole discretion and four who were elected by the common unitholders. Directors appointed by our general
	partner serve as directors for terms determined by our general partner. Directors elected by our common unitholders are divided into three classes serving staggered three-year terms. One of the four directors elected by our common unitholders was
	designated as the Class&nbsp;II elected director and will serve until our annual meeting of unitholders in 2016 as the term was renewed for three years during our 2013 annual meeting of unitholders; one director was designated as our Class&nbsp;III
	elected director and will serve until our annual meeting of unitholders in 2017 as the term was renewed for three years during our 2014 annual meeting of unitholders; and the remaining two directors were designated as the Class&nbsp;I elected
	directors and will serve until our annual meeting of unitholders in 2018, as their term was renewed for three years during our 2015 annual meeting of unitholders. At each subsequent annual meeting of unitholders, directors will be elected to succeed
	the class of directors whose terms have expired by a plurality of the votes of the common unitholders. Directors elected by our common unitholders will be nominated by the board of directors or by any limited partner or group of limited partners
	that holds at least 10% of the outstanding common units.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	With respect to our corporate governance, there are several significant differences between us
	and a domestic issuer in that the New York Stock Exchange does not require a listed limited partnership like us to have a majority of independent directors on our board of directors or to establish a compensation committee or a nominating/corporate
	governance committee.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We have two committees: an audit committee and a conflicts committee. Three independent members of our board of directors serve on
	a conflicts committee to review specific matters that the board believes may involve potential conflicts of interest. The conflicts committee determines if the resolution of the conflict of interest is fair and reasonable to us. The members of the
	conflicts committee may not be officers or employees of our general partner or directors, officers or employees of its affiliates, and must meet the independence standards established by the New York Stock Exchange to serve on an audit committee of
	a board of directors and certain other requirements. Any matters approved by the conflicts committee are conclusively deemed to be fair and reasonable to us, approved by all of our partners, and not a breach by our directors, our general partner or
	its affiliates of any duties any of them may owe us or our unitholders. The members of our conflicts committee are Messrs.&nbsp;John Karakadas, Serafeim Kriempardis and Dimitris Papastefanou Gkouras.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition, we have an audit committee of three independent directors. One of the members of the audit committee is an &#147;audit committee financial
	expert&#148; for purposes of SEC rules and regulations. The audit committee, among other things, reviews our external financial reporting, engages our external auditors and oversees our internal audit activities and procedures and the adequacy of
	our internal accounting controls. Our
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	96
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage99"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D153048D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	audit committee is comprised of Messrs. John Karakadas, Dimitris Papastefanou Gkouras&nbsp;and Serafeim Kriempardis and our audit committee financial expert is Mr.Serafeim&nbsp;Kriempardis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Employees of the Manager, a subsidiary of Navios Holdings, provide assistance to us and our operating subsidiaries pursuant to the Management Agreement and
	the Administrative Services Agreement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our Chief Executive Officer, Ms.&nbsp;Angeliki Frangou, and our Chief Financial Officer, Mr.&nbsp;Efstratios
	Desypris, allocate their time between managing our business and affairs and the business and affairs of Navios Holdings, and our Chief Executive Officer is also the Chief Executive Officer of Navios Acquisition, Navios Holdings and Navios Midstream.
	While the amount of time each of them allocate between our business and the business of Navios Holdings, Navios Acquisition and Navios Midstream varies from time to time depending on various circumstances and the respective needs of the business,
	such as their relative levels of strategic activities, we anticipate that each of them will allocate approximately one quarter of their time to our business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our officers and other individuals providing services to us or our subsidiaries may face a conflict regarding the allocation of their time between our
	business and the other business interests of Navios Midstream, Navios Holdings and Navios Acquisition. We intend to cause our officers to devote as much time to the management of our business and affairs as is necessary for the proper conduct of our
	business and affairs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our General Partner owes a fiduciary duty to our unitholders, subject to limitations. Our General Partner is liable, as General
	Partner, for all of our debts (to the extent not paid from our assets), except for indebtedness or other obligations that are expressly non-recourse to it. Whenever possible, the partnership agreement directs that we should incur indebtedness or
	other obligations that are non-recourse to our General Partner.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Whenever our General Partner makes a determination or takes or declines to take an action
	in its individual capacity rather than in its capacity as our General Partner, it is entitled to make such determination or to take or decline to take such other action free of any fiduciary duty or obligation whatsoever to us or any limited
	partner, and is not required to act in good faith or pursuant to any other standard imposed by our partnership agreement or under the Marshall Islands Act or any other law. Specifically, our General Partner will be considered to be acting in its
	individual capacity if it exercises its call right, pre-emptive rights or registration rights, consents or withholds consent to any merger or consolidation of the partnership, appoints any directors or votes for the appointment of any director,
	votes or refrains from voting on amendments to our partnership agreement that require a vote of the outstanding units, voluntarily withdraws from the partnership, transfers (to the extent permitted under our partnership agreement) or refrains from
	transferring its units, general partner interest or incentive distribution rights or votes upon the dissolution of the partnership. Actions of our General Partner, which are made in its individual capacity, are made by Navios Holdings as sole member
	of our General Partner.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	D. Employees
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Employees of
	the Manager provide assistance to us and our operating subsidiaries pursuant to the Management Agreement and the Administrative Services Agreement; therefore Navios Partners does not employ additional staff.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Manager crews its vessels primarily with Ukrainian, Polish, Filipino, Russian, Indian, Georgian, Romanian and Sri Lankan officers and Filipino, Georgian,
	Romanian, Ethiopian, Indian and Ukrainian seamen. For these nationalities, officers and seamen are referred to the Manager by local crewing agencies. The crewing agencies handle each seaman&#146;s training while the Manager handles their travel and
	payroll. Navios Holdings requires that all of its seamen have the qualifications and licenses required to comply with international regulations and shipping conventions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Manager also provides on-shore advisory, operational and administrative support to us pursuant to service agreements. Please see
	&#147;Item&nbsp;7.&nbsp;&#151; Major Unitholders and Related Party Transactions&#148;.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	97
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	E. Unit Ownership
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table sets forth certain information regarding beneficial ownership, as of March&nbsp;22, 2016, of&nbsp;our units by each of our officers and
	directors and by all of our directors and officers as a group. The information is not necessarily indicative of beneficial ownership for any other purposes. Under SEC rules, a&nbsp;person or entity beneficially owns any units that the person or
	entity has the right to acquire as of May&nbsp;21, 2016 (60&nbsp;days after March&nbsp;22, 2016)&nbsp;through the exercise of any unit option or other right. The percentage disclosed under &#147;Common Units Beneficially Owned&#148; is based on all
	outstanding common units (83,079,710), not including general partner units (1,695,509). Unless otherwise indicated, each person or entity has sole voting and investment power (or shares such powers with his or her spouse) with respect to the units
	set forth in the following table. Information for certain holders is based on information delivered to&nbsp;us.
</P>
